awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Development of a Miniaturized Multiwell Plate Reader
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project will be the alleviation of several current difficulties in the growth measurement of many bacterial species, especially anaerobic and other fastidious organisms. A large number of these species are naturally occurring in the human body, and they have recently been shown to play critical roles in allergies, autoimmune diseases, dietary health, cancer, infection response, and more. The study of these species is considered by many to be the next frontier of modern medicine, especially as current approaches to managing infectious diseases, such as traditional antibiotics, appear to be losing effectiveness. However, current measurement technology is largely incompatible with the specialized environments and chambers in which anaerobic organisms must be grown. There is therefore a large unmet need for better ways to measure anaerobic bacterial growth; this need is growing quickly as interest in the field increases. The ability to conduct high-throughput experiments in specialized environments will become critical as research into various human microbiomes accelerates, and demand for high-volume data grows. The existing market for high-throughput measurement devices is at least $300 million and growing; the proposed technology will expand that market to fields it has never served.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop technology for measuring growth of many bacterial samples in a format much smaller than currently available high-throughput devices. The rise of systems and computational biology demonstrates a growing demand for large amounts of quantitative data; the variety of microbes in the human body necessitates such an approach. However, this type of data is currently nearly impossible to collect in anaerobic and other specialized environments. This project aims to bring high-throughput growth measurement techniques to these environments by creating simplified, miniaturized hardware paired with advanced real-time analysis and control software. The project?s first objective is to refine a novel proof-of-concept optical density measurement method to achieve accuracy and precision comparable to traditional techniques, and verify using bacterial growth and inorganic liquid testing. The next goal is to design a hardware enclosure small and robust enough to allow compatibility with the smallest and most taxing environments. Finally, software will be developed to manage a high number of bacterial experiments (and devices) running in parallel without sacrificing data fidelity or high resolution. It is anticipated that the resulting high-throughput measurement system will greatly expand researchers' abilities to characterize microbes of increasing clinical relevance.

por.por_cntn:
In many areas of biological research, it is important to measure microbial growth. These measurements can gauge microbes' responses to things like drug treatments, availability of chemical resources, and the presence of other microbes. Recently, there has been a trend toward gathering large amounts of this data and processing it together to form nuanced conclusions. This is especially important as antibiotic resistance is on the rise and the scientific community looks to better target disease therapies.

However, the technology most commonly used to perform these measurements is very large and expensive, which prevents many laboratories from taking advantage of these techniques. This is especially true in the field of gut microbiome research, where all measurement must take place in a chamber with no oxygen present; most measurement instruments simply cannot fit in such a space. Because of this lack of accessibility, much remains to be discovered with regard to effective management of drug resistance, the effectiveness of probiotic therapies, and holistic management of the body’s microbiome.

We have used SBIR funding from the National Science Foundation under award number 1647768 to develop a miniaturized version of one commonly-used measurement device, called a multiwell plate reader, which is capable of measuring the growth of up to 96 samples simultaneously. To accomplish this, we needed to take a very early, academic prototype we had developed for our research and make it (1) more accurate and precise, (2) smaller and more rugged, and (3) capable of being controlled wirelessly, or at least without being physically tethered to a computer. There was no guarantee that we would be able to accomplish these goals, which made the development relatively high risk and is why we sought research and development seed funding from the NSF. The societal impact of success, however, would be great and could lead to a vast expansion of necessary scientific research and eventually better clinical therapies worldwide for nuanced, drug-resistant infections such as Clostridium difficile and tuberculosis.

We are happy to report that the outcome of this Phase I SBIR was greatly successful. Over the 16 months of grant-funded work, we have accomplished the above-described technical goals and produced a device which meets researchers’ requirements at a small fraction of the volume of other instruments, and at up to ten times lower cost. The device we have produced is also extremely portable and can be USB-powered, allowing use nearly anywhere. We have distributed this device to numerous sites throughout the United States for use in fields as diverse as gut microbe research, synthetic molecule production, tuberculosis characterization, and environmental testing. All users have reported that the new device represents a fundamental shift in their research abilities and will lead to greatly improved data and more reliable scientific outcomes.

Soon this device will be for sale to the general biological research community (and limited early adopter sales are already taking place as of 2018). We look forward to contributing to an increase in knowledge and understanding of microbial behavior, and any associated clinical improvements which emerge.
